text:
Hi all, a small question from a beginner.

I have a number of similar composite types, one of the fields of  which is an array (see MWE below), and a simple function `project!` which I want to operate iteratively on prealoocated arrays. The function uses the array from my composite type (in the example below it's a pointwise multiplicative factor, but it might be different for the other types, that's why I wrapped the arrays in a new type).

I hoped that as I have everything preallocated, application of `project!` would require 0 allocations, but as seen in the example below it's not like that. For  large size of arrays and large number of iterations, it seems to be not efficient.

If checked with profiler, it’s clear that the array from my structure is materialized every time I call `project!` (because of `getfield` command, I guess).

Is there any way to avoid this? Or, in general, do I do something wrong?
```struct ConstrainedByAmplitude <: AmplitudeConstrainedSet
    amp::Array{T} where T <: Real 
end

function project!(xp, x, feasset::ConstrainedByAmplitude)
    xp .= feasset.amp .* _unit_amp.(x)
end

@inline function _unit_amp(z)
    abs(z)≈0 ? 1 : z/abs(z)
end```
```julia> ttt = ConstrainedByAmplitude(rand(512, 512));
julia> x0 = one(ttt.amp);
julia> x1 = similar(x0);

julia> @btime project!($x1, $x0, $ttt)
  195.700 μs (4 allocations: 96 bytes)```
I tried to avoid this by “precalculating” functions for the particular implementations of my types, like below, but it didn’t help.
```function _actualise_projection(set)
    function actualised(xp,x)
        project!(xp,x,set)
    end
    return actualised
end```

Hi all, a small question from a beginner.

I have a number of similar composite types, one of the fields of  which is an array (see MWE below), and a simple function

which I want to operate iteratively on prealoocated arrays. The function uses the array from my composite type (in the example below it's a pointwise multiplicative factor, but it might be different for the other types, that's why I wrapped the arrays in a new type).

I hoped that as I have everything preallocated, application of

would require 0 allocations, but as seen in the example below it's not like that. For  large size of arrays and large number of iterations, it seems to be not efficient.

If checked with profiler, it’s clear that the array from my structure is materialized every time I call

command, I guess).

Is there any way to avoid this? Or, in general, do I do something wrong?

struct ConstrainedByAmplitude <: AmplitudeConstrainedSet
    amp::Array{T} where T <: Real 
end

function project!(xp, x, feasset::ConstrainedByAmplitude)
    xp .= feasset.amp .* _unit_amp.(x)
end

@inline function _unit_amp(z)
    abs(z)≈0 ? 1 : z/abs(z)

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
the problem lies in `amp::Array{T} where T <: Real`
that's a UnionAll, and so the type of `amp` is not defined by just being an instance of `ConstranedByAmplitude`

elements.text: that's a UnionAll, and so the type of
is not defined by just being an instance of

text: to solve this, make `ConstrainedByAmplitude` have a type parameter, restrict the eltype there and pass it through to the type definition of `amp`

elements.text: have a type parameter, restrict the eltype there and pass it through to the type definition of

text: Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/54802| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
Thanks, I'll try

I've just tried as follows:
```struct CA{T}<: AmplitudeConstrainedSet where T<:Real
           amp::Array{T} 
end

function p!(xp, x, feasset::CA)
           xp .= feasset.amp .* _unit_amp.(x)
end```
And I still have 4 allocations instead of 0
```julia> ttt = CA{Float64}(rand(512, 512));

julia> @btime p!($x1, $x0, $ttt)
  198.900 μs (4 allocations: 96 bytes)```

elements.text: And I still have 4 allocations instead of 0

text: `_unit_amp` is type unstable - if the condition is `true`, you return an `Int`

elements.text: is type unstable - if the condition is

you can investigate these kinds of issues with `@code_warntype`

text: usually allocations happen because of slices (none here) or type instabilities (probably the case here)

text: also, what's `x1`?
If I do the same just with an array, (and not an array as field from a structure), I've got 0 allocations.

elements.text: If I do the same just with an array, (and not an array as field from a structure), I've got 0 allocations.

text: What I've read, is that `getfield` materializes the array (similar to slice): <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55653932/broadcast-operator-over-field-of-an-array-of-structures-julia>

attachments.title: Broadcast operator over field of an array of structures (Julia)
attachments.text: I have an array instantiated structures (of the same type). I would like to change the value of a certain field of these structures. For performance reasons I would like to avoid using a for loop. ...
attachments.fallback: Stack Overflow: Broadcast operator over field of an array of structures (Julia)

text: that's a good point
still, that only explains one of the remaining allocations - and also doesn't explain the size! 64 bytes is just much less than the size of that array

text: Ah, no - I forgot :man-facepalming:
`Array{Float64}` is an abstract type - the dimensions are missing! `Array{Float64,1}` would be a concrete type (or `Vector{Float64}`, which is an alias to the former)

elements.text: is an abstract type - the dimensions are missing!
, which is an alias to the former)
